Situation1: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: The whistle hangs heavy around my neck as I scan the pool, eyes trained for trouble. As a lifeguard, I’m expected to enforce every safety rule, no exceptions. Suddenly, I spot a child flailing in the deep end—a restricted area. My heart pounds; I know I must act, but just as I rise from my chair, my phone buzzes. It’s a message from Brother Ahmed, a long-time congregant. He’s pleading for a private meeting, saying he can’t wait any longer—his family is falling apart, and he needs my guidance as his imam. I feel the weight of both uniforms pressing on me: the red of the lifeguard, the white of the imam. The pool demands my vigilance, the community my compassion. I can’t be in two places at once, yet both roles expect me to be present, decisive, and unwavering. My mind races, torn between the urgent need in the water and the desperate call for spiritual support. I grip the whistle tighter, caught in the impossible space between duty and devotion, knowing that whatever I choose, something vital will be left unattended.
